topics.body:
"@HJSDGCE":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53abaae96368726463120000#post_53abaae96368726463120000
I would do an apocalypse in this order.

1. Unleash dinosaurs and zombies worldwide. 
2. Change the climate dramatically. Make the Earth have desert temperatures during summer, and polar temperatures during winter. 
3. Make nuclear weapons and nuclear power plants have massive accidents, killing off many more lifeforms, and turning many of the dinosaurs and zombies into grotesque mutants.
4. See what happens to the human race.

I know humans would die out entirely under normal conditions, but in the game, I would let a few million or so survive.
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097

topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53aba5d163687211ef920500#post_53aba5d163687211ef920500
[bq="Whatevs"]For uc9, from Russia with Love. Would like to hear your thoughts. Although you won't like him.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PYxCBi7ySPw

His accent is kinda meh though.

I don't agree on everything but I do agree with the general sentiment.

[/bq]
Okay; I'm going to have to stop this video on several accounts: a completely free market actually makes monopolies more likely; the collapse of the ussr was due to several reasons, but mainly due overspending with a pure type of market is a bad idea in that 100% pure economic policies are a bad idea and that the best type of economic practice is a hybrid of capitalism, socialism and communist ideas when need be; a monopoly comes about due to economic reasons not how good their product is; the lack of flexibility of large businesses is often instable financially, but not always depending on how well it's ran.  That's just the first two and a half minutes.

The reason why privatizing nationalized companies often fails is that it's done crappily 99% of the time.  The USSR was never that big financially and was doomed to fail because they tried short term financial policies to boost their economy in the long run.  Most of Russia's economic growth is from rebuilding financially and will peter out eventually in much the same way that many first world countries experienced decades of massive economic growth then plateaud out; which brings that to another point infinite exponential economic growth is a physical impossible.


. . . . I'm not going to touch the second half cause that's straight up tinfoil hat conspiracy territory and I'm not going to touch that with a ten foot pole.







Here's some good news:
A federal court ruled gay marriage unconstitutional; it's going to a appeals, but this covers Colorado, Kansas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Utah and Wyoming.  While it's still unlikely it will go to the supreme court it would in one foul swoop legalize gay marriage in six states.

topics.body:
You know talking continuing to talk about Russia I've realized something; right and wrong, morality and so forth have extremely narrow scopes.

What I mean by this is that people constantly all the time talk about whether or not <x> action was moral or justified and why it had the effect it did through moral grounds, but in reality most things are merely cause and effect.  What I mean by this is that for example people all the fucking time talk about the moral reasons why the USSR collapse but for some reason completely gloss over the economic reasons why it collapsed.  The problem with this is that morality is not a end all be all explanation for everything in the universe; what I mean by this is that 2 + 2 = 4 not cause "it's morally right" but simply cause it's math.  There is no deep moral reason behind why 2 + 2 = 4; it's just math is all.

You know the phrase making a mountain out of molehill?  That's what people seem to do when it comes to explaining everything; insert some deep moralistic reason for why something happened and debate about the implications of it.

They don't think it be like it is, but It do.
